title: Kalinga Grand Medical Mission Kalinga sa UCU Grand Medical Mission

content: The External Affairs and Linkages Department of Urdaneta City University proudly participated in the "Kalinga sa UCU Grand Medical Mission" a large-scale healthcare initiative organized by the Kalinga Partylist. This event was conceived as a response to the persistent need for accessible healthcare services among underserved communities in and around Urdaneta City. The medical mission reflects a shared commitment between the university, government agencies, and civic organizations to uphold public welfare through responsive and inclusive service delivery. Recognizing the university’s integral role in community development, the department saw this initiative as an opportunity to extend its impact beyond academic boundaries and contribute meaningfully to addressing pressing societal issues. The activity formed part of the university’s broader agenda to promote social responsibility, foster institutional partnerships, and reinforce its role as a key stakeholder in public service.

sections.title: This projects aims to:
items: Provide immediate relief to beneficiaries in need of medical attention
Support the successful execution of a community-centered health mission
Demonstrate the practical relevance of the university’s mission to serve the public good
Raise awareness on the importance of preventive healthcare

sections.title: Contributions to the Sustainable Development Goals
content: The medical mission contributed significantly to several United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Foremost among these is SDG 3 (Good Health and Well-being), which advocates for ensuring healthy lives and promoting well-being for all at all ages. By offering free consultations, medications, and other essential health services, the mission addressed health inequalities and reduced barriers to medical access for vulnerable sectors. Additionally, the initiative supported SDG 10 (Reduced Inequalities) by reaching out to marginalized populations, thereby promoting inclusivity in healthcare provision. SDG 17 (Partnerships for the Goals) was also central to the event, as the mission was a product of collaboration among government bodies, the academic sector, and civil society—demonstrating how collective action can lead to meaningful and measurable social impact. The event also resonated with the university’s commitment to civic engagement, sustainability, and cross-sector collaboration.

columns.title: General Assessment
content: The participation of the External Affairs and Linkages Department in the grand medical mission was highly impactful and widely appreciated. The event was well-organized, drew a significant number of beneficiaries, and successfully provided essential healthcare to those who needed it most. Feedback from both the public and participating partners was overwhelmingly positive, with many commending the professionalism, compassion, and efficiency demonstrated throughout the event. The department’s role was recognized as a vital component in the event’s success, especially in facilitating coordination among multiple entities. Moreover, the activity served as a concrete demonstration of the university’s capacity to lead in community-based initiatives and contribute meaningfully to social development. The department not only fulfilled its logistical duties but also exemplified leadership in community relations, showcasing the value of academic institutions as partners in national and local development efforts.

columns.title: Recommendations
content: To build on the momentum of this successful initiative, it is recommended that the External Affairs and Linkages Department institutionalize its involvement in similar outreach missions as part of its regular program of activities. Future events could benefit from the inclusion of more comprehensive services such as dental check-ups, mental health consultations, and health education sessions focused on nutrition, hygiene, and disease prevention. Expanding the scope and reach of these programs to nearby rural areas can help broaden the impact of the university’s outreach efforts. The department should also consider forming a standing committee on community health initiatives, composed of representatives from various university departments and partner organizations, to ensure continuous planning and program development. Furthermore, increasing the involvement of students—particularly those in health sciences, social work, and public administration—can provide valuable experiential learning while reinforcing the university’s role in developing civic-minded graduates. Finally, improved data collection and post-event evaluation mechanisms should be implemented to better measure outcomes, gather community feedback, and guide improvements for future outreach initiatives.

title: MOA Signing of UCU and Pangasinan 2nd Provincial Mobile Force Company

content: Urdaneta City University (UCU) and the Pangasinan 2nd Provincial Mobile Force Company (PMFC) formalized their collaboration through a Memorandum of Agreement (MOA) signing, facilitated by the Office of External Affairs and Linkages. The partnership emerged from ongoing dialogues on enhancing campus safety, community engagement, and proactive peace-building efforts in Urdaneta City and neighboring areas. By institutionalizing shared responsibilities, both parties aim to leverage their respective strengths—UCU’s educational resources and PMFC’s security expertise—to cultivate a safer, more resilient community.

sections.title: This projects aims to:
items: Strengthen institutional cooperation between UCU and the PMFC to support peace, order, and public safety on and off campus.
Establish clear protocols for joint community-oriented programs such as safety awareness seminars, emergency preparedness drills, and youth outreach initiatives.
Provide learning opportunities for students—especially those in criminology and social sciences—through internships, lectures, and field activities with PMFC personnel.
Foster mutual trust and open communication channels between the university community and law-enforcement officers.

sections.title: Contributions to the Sustainable Development Goals
content: The MOA directly advances SDG 4 (Quality Education) by integrating practical, community-based security learning into the curriculum; SDG 16 (Peace, Justice, and Strong Institutions) by promoting peaceful, inclusive environments and strengthening local institutions through collaboration; and SDG 17 (Partnerships for the Goals) by formalizing a multi-stakeholder partnership that aligns educational and security objectives for community benefit.

columns.title: General Assessment
content: The event was executed smoothly and achieved its primary aim of formalizing the partnership. Stakeholders expressed strong commitment, and immediate next steps—such as forming a joint working committee and scheduling initial safety seminars—were agreed upon. The presence of students and local officials underscored community buy-in, while the clear delineation of roles in the MOA sets a solid foundation for sustained collaboration.

columns.title: Recommendations
content: To ensure the success and sustainability of the partnership between Urdaneta City University and the Pangasinan 2nd Provincial Mobile Force Company, it is recommended to convene the joint working committee within one month to finalize activity timelines and define specific roles and responsibilities. Monitoring the impact of the collaboration is also essential; this can be achieved by developing simple metrics such as incident reports, seminar attendance, and student feedback to evaluate effectiveness and inform continuous improvement. Broadening participation across the university is encouraged by involving student organizations and various academic departments to integrate safety and peace-building themes into both curricular and co-curricular programs. Communicating the success of joint initiatives through campus media and local press will help build public trust, promote transparency, and inspire broader community support. Lastly, seeking complementary partners—such as local NGOs or health agencies—can expand the scope of the collaboration to include mental health support, disaster preparedness, and other community resilience efforts, thereby amplifying the overall impact of the MOA.
